p.s: Boris Johnson tries to draw a convincing picture of dangerous, to let his audience take action in the future by using words like our or we to create a sense of community so everybody feels called to handle and by using stylistic devices to underlined the necessity of changing something.
The speech can be divided in four parts.
In the first part (l. 1-9) the speaker is welcoming everybody to COP26 (l. 1) and introduce the topic by comparing it to a James Bond movie.
He compare is a fictional machine the doomsday device (l. 7) the fast temperature rising caused by the climate change.
Through this comparison he directly creates a picture how big this problem is and that it will destroy our world completely if we don't help like James Bond did in the movie.
He also uses inclusive pronouns like we (l. 9) to address directly to the audience so that everybody feels to be called.
In the next part (l. 10-21) Boris Johnson mentions the last climate conferences and compares it to the climate conference COP26.
He points out to that COP26 should be a turning point in this topic and that it is time to handle by using again a direct address to the audience (l. 14f.).

In the next line the speaker uses in a enumeration (l. 14) to underline all the topics where the population can make a change, so that the audience does not only feel addressed to handle but also what to do for solving the climate change.

To encourage the people to take action Boris does not only usesuse inclusive pronouns he sends a task, a duty to the people, an apealappeal that thethey must help (l. 18-21) to solve the problem which was caused 200 years ago.
The next part (l. 22-37) the britishBritish Prime Minister explains that for making a big change we need more financial support which is possible.
By using again pronouns like our (l. 24) he creates that sense of community that people who are able to sponsor how to do it for everybody's life.
To strengthen this comment he names an example how the UK and the dependence on coal (l. 28f.).
By underlining in the next line the word we through an anaphora (l. 30) Boris Johnson names to specifically that we the population is the only possibility to make a change.

Furthermore he points out what will happen if we fail by using emotional expressions (l. 40) and by repeatinglyrepeatedly naming the next generations (l. 38) to create a feeling of duty to help Internet the ones who are not helping feel bad for it.
Through another anaphora (l. 45-47) Boris Johnson strengthenstrengthens this comment by using now facts how we can help.
In the last part (l. 48-52) the speaker creates a conclusion to the beginning by mentioning the James Bond movie.
He says that we may not feel or look like James Bond but we have the same opportunities as him and that we can fight against climate change.
In conclusion uses Boris many emotions and repetitions to convince the audience to help fight against climate change.
He uses the sense of comunitycommunity to touch the audience.
